Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery neck-amphora; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of scene with frontal chariot (lower parts of two horses, one with traces in added white, part of chariot with added red, and legs of female, labelled Eriphyle, with white pattern on peplos and holding partly preserved necklace); below, brown band above trace of lower frieze, probably of animals.
Producer name: Attributed to a Follower of: The Tyrrhenian Group
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
See also Cahn, H. A. and Simon, E., Tainia, Festschrift für Roland Hampe. Mainz, 1978, pl. 24, no. 3. LIMC I, Amphiaraos 19. Venit notes that Bothmer attributes the sherd to the Prometheus Painter.
Bibliographic references: Payne 1931 / Necrocorinthia. A study of corinthian art in the archaic period (p. 140)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 220, no. B63)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 232, no. 1)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0026) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 92, pl. I, no. 36)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
